    The Expanding Role of Chemistry in Optimizing Proteins for Human Health Applications

    Miniperspective

    • Bart I. Roman*
      Bart I. Roman
      Research Group SynBioC, Department of Green Chemistry and Technology, Faculty of Bioscience Engineering, Universiteit Gent, Coupure Links 653, 9000 Gent, Belgium
      Cancer Research Institute Ghent (CRIG), Corneel Heymanslaan 10, 9000 Gent, Belgium
      *Email: [emailÂ protected]
      More by Bart I. Roman
      View Biography
      https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9407-6721
    Cite this: J. Med. Chem. 2021, 64, 11, 7179â7188
    Publication Date (Web):May 20, 2021

    Publication History

    • Published online20 May 2021

    SUBJECTS:
    • Modification,
    • Peptides and proteins,
    • Monomers,
    • Small molecules,
    • Pharmaceuticals
    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Over the past decades, therapeutics based on biological macromolecules and cells have successfully entered the clinical arena and progressively occupied an increasing share of what once was almost exclusively small molecule territory. This perspective explores the opportunities for chemists at the interface between biologics and small molecule-based products. It provides concrete examples by zooming in on the area of post-translational protein modification. The conclusion is that, rather than diminishing the relevance of chemistry in the pharmaceutical enterprise, the advent of the biologics has provided an additional playing field for synthetic and medicinal chemists, where they can contribute to the efficacy and scope of applicability of biological entities in a collaborative effort to transformatively address unmet medical needs.

    When WÃ¶hler successfully prepared urea from inorganic reagents in 1828,(1) and Kolbe converted carbon disulfide to acetic acid 17 years later,(2) they not only contributed to the downfall of vitalism. Their feats also heralded the age of modern organic chemistry: given skill and effort, scientific progress would eventually enable the synthesis of any molecule, be it natural or designed (Figure 1). By the end of the 19th century, the chemical industry produced a whole array of dyes and other chemicals, and also introduced what would become the worldâs first blockbuster drug: acetylsalicylic acid (Aspirin, Bayer, 1899).(3,4) (In which Kolbe also played an important role by determining the structure and developing a synthesis of salicylic acid in 1859.(5)) Add another 70 years, and the field of synthetic organic chemistry came to full maturity with the preparation of vitamin B12 by Woodward and Eschenmoser.(6â8) Enter the blockbuster era during which pharmaceutical companies and research institutions successfully developed an armamentarium of small molecule drugs that have provided options to increase our wellbeing and live longer lives.(9)

    Looking beyond chemistry, the achievements of WÃ¶hler and Kolbe come forth from the ancient human desire to be able to fully characterize, understand, and create all molecules of life, and ultimately living systems.(22â24) A second scientific disciplineâwith remarkable parallels to chemistryâthat came forth from this desire is molecular biology. Inevitably, given the greater complexity of the systems under study, molecular (and ultimately synthetic) biology came to maturation later than chemistry. Since the 1980s, however, synthetic biology has achieved pinnacles equivalent to those in total chemical synthesis with the preparation of natural and engineered biological macromolecules, up to the level of fully functional proteins and genomes, from simple chemical building blocks (Figure 1).(22,23,25) This has enabled the biotechnological industry to generate a continuous output of innovative therapeutic approaches employing oligonucleotides, proteins, cells, and genetic engineering, among others, over the past decades.(26) Biologics have been developed against targets that were challenging or impossible to manipulate with small molecules and have brought benefit in previously unmet medical needs such as psoriasis, Crohnâs disease, and rheumatoid arthritis.(27â29) They have enabled the introduction of new treatment paradigms and were also more frequently first-in-class agents. The absolute and relative increase in the number of regulatory approvals for biologics(30) is, in some ways, still an underestimation of the true impact that these agents have made. (Although cost-effectiveness is worthy of a debate on its own, the higher economic valuation of biologics may to a certain extent be a better measure of their importance.) The biotech revolution is still in full swing, and its products are continuing to gain pharmaceutical market share.(31â33) Small molecules are no longer the rule, and biologics no longer the exception.

    Medicinal chemists, then, have perceived this evolution in diverging ways.(34) Part of the community has felt threatened in terms of long-term employment perspectives or has experienced an impact on morale due the effectiveness of biologics in indications where small molecules had previously failed. Others have downplayed the rise of biologics and point toward their high cost, lack of oral availability, and distribution to target organs, or other disadvantages, perhaps in search of confirmation of the continued relevance of their own field.

    Rather than fearing or playing down the biotech revolution, however, chemists should play along and see the opportunities rather than the threats. Small molecule drugs and medicinal chemistry as we know them will remain relevant as such, but more importantly, there is a new and creative role for chemists in biologics development as well. We must move past the classical view of small molecules and biologics as separate, or worse, competing technologies: biotechnology and chemistry are at their most powerful when they labor hand in hand in search of the best possible medicinal products.

    There are many precedents: fermentation has long helped chemists to produce high-value small molecules, and increasingly chemistry helps to modify biologics to make them better fit for purpose.(35) Especially in the field of protein modification, chemistry has a lot to offer.(36) Notable examples of engineered protein-based products already in the market or in advanced development stages include synthetic glycoprotein vaccines for which a chemical step is used to conjugate the carbohydrate antigen to a carrier protein.(37,38) Other well-known examples are chemically modified protein drugs with improved pharmacokinetics or lowered immunogenicity, antibody conjugates for the targeted delivery of therapeutics, and labeled macromolecules for imaging applications.(39â41)

    Despite the successful infiltration of these and many related products in the pharmaceutical market, much of the potential of protein-based pharmaceuticals remains untapped due to the inadequacy of current chemical methodology to modify proteins in a highly controlled fashion. In small molecule drug discovery, hit expansion and lead optimization involve the synthesis of large libraries of analogues to determine structureâactivity relationships and to optimize potency, safety, and pharmacokinetics. These synthesis campaigns have greatly benefited from enabling technologies such as late-stage modification strategies, combinatorial chemistry, and high-throughput chemistry, which deliver homogeneous products of well-defined structure in a time- and cost-efficient manner.(42,43) Likewise, peptides and proteins make use of structural modification strategies to enhance developability.(44â46) In contrast to small molecules, however, library synthesis can be less straightforward here, both in terms of the modification of specific residues (e.g., when requiring resynthesis, designed mutations, or directed evolution) and with regard to conjugation strategies (e.g., site-specific PEGylation).(47â50) These efforts would greatly benefit from additional site-specific âlate-stageâ peptide and protein modification strategies facilitating high-throughput library synthesis.(51,52)

    The large and unmet need for new and improved chemical technologies for post-translational protein modification constitutes an exciting opportunity for synthetic and medicinal chemists.(52) In the following paragraphs, a few unanswered challenges and opportunities in this area will be discussed. This perspective focuses on methods that directly modify native (and not engineered) proteins, as it may be argued that native protein modification bears more intrinsic potential for approximating the âidealâ route toward a target protein product. This is reflected in the growing interest in native protein modification by synthetic organic chemists that have previously focused on small molecules, and in their intensive collaborations with protein chemistry laboratories.(53â57) Of course, methods based on the modification of unnatural amino acids inserted via genetic engineering will remain of high utility as well, as will enzymatic methods.(58â60)

    For any protein modification technology to be valuable, the first and foremost condition is that it does not negatively affect the intended protein function. As that function is determined by shape and hence by chemical structure, any method will therefore primarily be judged by its ability to deliver site-specific modifications resulting in a homogeneous product of defined (primary) structure. It is important to realize that site-specific, in this context, refers to the modification of a single instance of a particular amino acid, thus implying chemoselectivity not only toward one amino acid type (in this context termed âsite-selectivityâ), but also toward a particular occurrence of that amino acid in the sequence.

    Achieving a high degree of site-specificity directly depends on the ability to identify and exploit the particularities of the microenvironment of a candidate target residue, in terms of chemical nature and/or spatial characteristics. A successful strategy in this context has been to target the N- or C-termini. These are mostly accessible, often not implicated in protein function, and allow for steric and electronic differentiation. Recently, for example, MacMillan and co-workers have developed a site-specific decarboxylative alkylation at the C-terminus of native proteins (Figure 2).(54) For human insulin, exclusive modification of the A-chain C-terminus was achieved. The transformation proceeds via a visible-light-mediated single-electron transfer (SET) mechanism. The observed specificity for the C-terminal carboxylate with respect to aspartic and glutamic acid residues was anticipated because of their inherently different oxidation potentials, due to the respective formation of a heteroatom-stabilized Î±-amino radical and a nonstabilized carbon-centered primary radical. The fundamental insights and intuition of synthetic organic chemists, developed by working on small molecules, are thus of direct value in solving problems of site-specificity (and, more general, site-selectivity) in protein modification.

    Whereas C-terminal and N-terminal modifications have logically focused on decarboxylation and amine chemistry, respectively, a larger pool of functional groups and reaction types can be exploited when targeting native in-chain residues (Figure 2). An informative overview of recent advances in the field, structured per residue and accessible to the organic chemist, was compiled by Baran and co-workers.(53) Two main points of inspiration for chemists can be drawn from this and other review papers.(36,52,68â70) First, an outstanding challenge is to find effective ways to modify underserved canonical amino acids, notably the aliphatic, carboxylate, aliphatic alcohol, and histidine residues. Second, for residues that at first sight can be targeted by a myriad of existing methods, reactions with enhanced site-specificity remain in demand. Lysine modification chemistry, for example, often lacks sufficient control to select between the various Îµ-amino groups of in-chain residues (and to a lesser extent the N-terminal Î±-amino group). Cysteine thiol modification methods are abundant, but the formed adducts frequently display suboptimal stability.

    Cys and Lys modification are cornerstone strategies in the production of biologics, and the properties of the resulting linkage directly impact the clinical success or failure of the resulting products, as can be illustrated for antibodyâdrug conjugates (ADCs).(40,71) Most ADCsâFDA-approved or in advanced clinical developmentâare essentially produced using one of two âclassicâ linker technologies: amide bond formation by conjugation to native lysine residues or Michael addition of a cysteine thiol to a maleimide (Figure 2, Table 1). Accessible Lys residues are relatively abundant in monoclonal antibodies (mAbs). Because current lysine modification chemistries are not site-specific, conjugation processes are of stochastic nature and produce heterogeneous products in terms of site of attachment and drug loading (drugâantibody ratio, DAR). This is problematic in production and formulation, and negatively affects the pharmacokinetics and the therapeutic index of the drug product. The impact of these issues became clear with the first marketed ADC, Gemtuzumab ozogamicin (Mylotarg, Wyeth), an anti-CD33 monoclonal antibodyâcalicheamicin construct for the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia. It is produced via random lysine conjugation and used as a heterogeneous mixture with a broad drug loading distribution (1â8 per molecule) and contains 50% of unconjugated mAb. These deficiencies contributed to off-target effects and serious toxicity issues, which led to market withdrawal of the product in 2010 (it was later reapproved).(18,71,72) Significant improvements in lysine-based ADC construction meanwhile have enabled the introduction and safe use of several lysine-conjugated ADCs, but the technology remains random in nature. Cysteine conjugation techniques can display superior site-specificity (e.g., at interchain thiols) and may deliver better DAR control, but chiefly use maleimide-type chemistry that is slowly reversible under physiological conditions causing off-target toxicity.(73,74) New techniques for in-chain residue modification with improved site-specificity as well as reduced deconjugation rates have meanwhile been developed, but of these, the chemical methods remain focused on thiol-maleimide or similar reactions.(71,75â81)

    Table 1. FDA-Approved AntibodyâDrug Conjugates Up to and Including 2020, Sorted by Bioconjugation Methodology and Year of Approvala()
    a

    Abbreviations and compound code names used in this table: ALCL, anaplastic large cell lymphoma; AML, acute myeloid leukemia; BC, breast cancer BCMA, B-cell maturation antigen; BCP-ALL, B-cell precursor acute lymphoblastic leukemia; CTCL, cutaneous T-cell lymphoma; DLBCL, diffuse large B-cell lymphoma; DM1, mertansine, thiol-containing maytansinoid; HCL, Hairy cell leukemia; HL, Hodgkin lymphoma; la, locally advanced; m, metastatic; mcMMAF, maleimidocaproyl monomethyl auristatin F; MMAE, monomethyl auristatin E; MM, multiple myeloma; PE, 38 kDa fragment of Pseudomonas exotoxin A; PTCL, peripheral T-cell lymphoma; R/R, relapsed/refractory; s, systemic; SN-38, active metabolite of irinotecan; TNBC, triple negative breast cancer.

    b

    Gemtuzumab ozogamicin was withdrawn from the market in 2010 and reapproved in 2017.

    c

    Trastuzumab deruxtecan received FDA approval for unresectable and/or metastatic breast cancer and locally advanced or metastatic HER2-positive gastric adenocarcinomas.

    This underlines the unmet need for fundamentally novel post-translational protein modification chemistry, both for commonly targeted residues and for underserved residues. Current transformations of native residues are chiefly situated in the realm of âclassicalâ, ionic (and cycloaddition) chemistry.(68) Variations on such closed-shell transformations are seldomly able to provide disruptive advances in site-selectivity and site-specificity: they all share fundamental issues of chemo- and regioselectivity, since protein residues (amines, thiols, alcohols, carboxylic acids, and amides) readily engage in similar ionic transformations. Many procedures and reagents commonly employed in synthetic closed-shell reactions are, moreover, not compatible with biologically ambient conditions (e.g., due to trapping of cationic or anionic intermediates in an aqueous environment, attenuated nucleophilicity, poor kinetics at room temperature). There are notable exceptions, however, where âclassicalâ methods display remarkable reactivity under mild conditions. Ball, for example, has developed a site-selective, Cu(II)-mediated backbone NâH modification in peptides and proteins, which is directed by a neighboring histidine residue and proceeds under ambient and aqueous conditions (Figure 2).(63) Another instance is Penteluteâs cysteine conjugation chemistry, which enables the introduction of probes and proteins using a perfluoroaryl linker.(91) Although this method is able to site-specifically target one cysteine residue in a protein, it requires the presence or engineering of a four-amino-acid sequence (Phe-Cys-Pro-Phe, called the âÏ-clampâ).

    A wealth of novel reactivity (for producing biological therapeutics, but also for bioconjugation in general) can come from complementing, fundamentally different chemistry using open-shell mechanisms.(54,70,92,93) Contrary to the general notion, radical chemistry can afford selectivity and complexity in a controlled fashion. It can be run in open flasks and is generally inert to the wealth of functionalities present in biologics. Radicals enable otherwise inaccessible chemistry because of reactivity umpolung and insensitivity to steric crowding. Closed-shell reactions have low to moderate rate constants ranging from 10â3 (Staudinger) to 103 Mâ1 sâ1 (cycloadditions). Thus, relatively high concentrations of reagents are required to obtain meaningful reaction yields, causing solubility and (in bioconjugation applications in living systems) toxicity problems.(94) The rate constants of transformations involving open-shell intermediates are several orders of magnitude higher (105â109 Mâ1 sâ1) and limit the concentration issue.(95) Open-shell reactions thus possess unique innate properties that render them kinetically and thermodynamically superior to classical modification techniques in terms of fundamental and application potential in post-translational protein modification.

    Small-molecule synthesis has recently witnessed a renaissance of radical chemistry, and enabling technologies such as electrochemistry and photoredox catalysis concomitantly have come (back) to the forefront.(93,96â98) Chemists with interest in drug discovery must fully exploit this momentum and grasp the opportunity to apply this wealth of new technology to the modification of (therapeutically relevant) biological macromolecules. Reports providing proof-of-principle have recently emerged (Figure 2). Besides the previously described site-specific decarboxylative alkylation at the C-terminus of insulin using photoredox chemistry by MacMillan et al., the groups of Gouverneur and Davis have demonstrated the applicability of chemically initiated radical reactions in native protein modification. In an extension of the scope of Baranâs sulfinate-based radical chemistry, they realized a chemoselective trifluoromethylation of tryptophan residues in proteins such as myoglobin on a preparative (mg) scale.(55,99) This modification was, moreover, accomplished at buried Trp sites, thereby displaying compatibility with other approaches that for steric reasons target accessible surface Trp residues.(100) âClassicalâ electrophilic approaches, also reported by Davis and Gouverneur et al., had directed trifluoromethylation toward cysteine residues, further illustrating the fundamentally different selectivity that can be obtained using open-shell mechanisms.(101) The need for organic chemists in fine-tuning reaction conditions for particular protein scaffolds and applications is further evidenced by earlier reports on the photochemically induced radical trifluoromethylations of peptides and proteins, which noted yet different selectivities.(102â104) The residue tunability by sulfinates continues to be developed: different alkyl sulfinates were recently used to leverage the innate reactivity of protonated His residues (at the C2 position) in unprotected, complex, bioactive peptides.(66) The broad scope of the sulfinate technology and other innovative protein modification methods will greatly facilitate the production of libraries for structureâactivity and safety studies and pharmacological optimization, similar to what has long been possible for small molecules.

    Evidence of the potential of electrochemistry in radical post-translational modification of native protein residues was provided by Song et al. in their direct, site-selective selective bioconjugation of tyrosine residues in insulin and myoglobin using phenotiazines (Figure 2).(65) Initial progress toward the site-selective targeting of in-chain carboxylate residues can be found in the photoinduced reaction of tetrazoles with surface-exposed glutamic acid residues in myoglobin, as reported by Luo et al. (Figure 2).(64) All of the above transformations proceed under (near)-biologically ambient conditions and can be considered early successes in what we believe to become enabling technologies in translational research.

    Realistically, new methods will first have to prove their merits on small molecules before their scope will be extended to peptides and proteins. Some transformations will only be applicable to a subset of proteins but may still be of great translational value. Smaller vectors, for example, currently receive great attention as a substitute to full-length antibodies in certain applications because of superior tissue targeting.(105â108) These entities may tolerate greater insults in terms of reaction conditions, as has been demonstrated for nanobodies with respect to full monoclonal antibodies.(109,110) In addition, the development of high-value biomaterials often relies on the modification of more ârobustâ peptides and proteins like gelatin.(111)

    Medicinal chemists may also contribute to the field of biological therapeutics through their experience in computational drug discovery. Calculations, modeling, structure-based design, and virtual screening techniques, common in small molecule drug discovery, can be adapted to solve problems in the structural modification of biologics, in terms of both reagent and residue selection and target structure design. Such tools are increasingly popular in post-translational protein modification, where they offer information on the orthogonality of reactions, and the location and chemical potential of hyperreactive instances of a particular amino acid that may engage in a site-specific modification.(112â114) Still more refined techniques are needed, however, to accurately model these complex phenomena. Returning to the C-terminal modification of the A-chain of insulin by MacMillan, for example, a different but related set of conditions later unexpectedly led to selective modification of the B-chain C-terminus, for reasons that remain to be understood.(115)

    This perspective has focused on the expanding role of chemists in optimizing protein therapeutics and in broadening their scope of application. Besides therapeutics, also the development of synthetic vaccines,(116) diagnostics,(117,118) theranostics,(105) and biomaterials,(119) among others, increasingly relies on the chemical modification of (native) proteins. Myriad opportunities for organic and medicinal chemists exist for other classes of biologics as well. These include, for example, modifications of oligonucleotides or in CRISPR-Cas9-associated base editing that increase stability or enable targeted delivery.(120â122) Another opportunity for the enhancement of advanced therapeutics (e.g., CAR T cells and CRISPR-Cas9-based therapies) is the development of chemically gated in vivo control systems.(123â125) Regardless of the exact nature of the substrate, the point remains that chemistry and biology in the future will increasingly work together to provide better solutions to unmet medical needs. I wish to end by speculating that this collaboration will be an enabling factor in the maturation of precision medicine: a stratified approach with tailor-made products for narrow patient populations, providing real cure instead of disease control. Perhaps the true change in landscape for medicinal chemists lies there: not the era of chemistry is over, but rather the era of âone size fits allâ blockbuster drugs.

        Meanwell, N. A.; Ewing, W. R. In Praise of Remarkably Powerful Centamolecular Therapeutic Agents. ACS Med. Chem. Lett. 2019, 10 (8), 1094â 1097, Â DOI: 10.1021/acsmedchemlett.9b00286
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        9
        In Praise of Remarkably Powerful Centamolecular Therapeutic Agents
        Meanwell, Nicholas A.; Ewing, William R.
        ACS Medicinal Chemistry Letters (2019), 10 (8), 1094-1097CODEN: AMCLCT; ISSN:1948-5875. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. While biol. medications have addressed many challenging therapeutic targets, the pharmacopeia is still dominated by centamols. In this viewpoint, we illustrate the impact of centamol. drugs on mortality and morbidity due to chronic viral infections and present select examples from other disease areas that highlight some of their remarkably powerful biochem. effects.

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        13
        First total synthesis of taxol. 1. Functionalization of the B ring
        Holton, Robert A.; Somoza, Carmen; Kim, Hyeong Baik; Liang, Feng; Biediger, Ronald J.; Boatman, P. Douglas; Shindo, Mitsuru; Smith, Chase C.; Kim, Soekchan; et al.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1994), 116 (4), 1597-8CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        Beginning stages of a total synthesis of the anti-tumor agent taxol were described. These stages result in the prepn. of an intermediate having three rings in which 6 stereocenters of the natural product are set. The key feature of this part of the total synthesis is control of conformation and reactivity in the bicyclo[5.3.1]undecane ring system. Thus, the diol I, a taxusin intermediate readily available from camphor, was transformed to the lactone carbonate II in 12 steps and 40% overall yield.

        Jackson, D. A.; Symons, R. H.; Berg, P. Biochemical Method for Inserting New Genetic Information into DNA of Simian Virus 40: Circular SV40 DNA Molecules Containing Lambda Phage Genes and the Galactose Operon of Escherichia Coli. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1972, 69 (10), 2904â 2909, Â DOI: 10.1073/pnas.69.10.2904
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        14
        Biochemical method for inserting new genetic information into DNA of Simian Virus 40. Circular SV40 DNA molecules containing lambda phage genes and the galactose operon of Escherichia coli
        Jackson, David A.; Symons, Robert H.; Berg, Paul
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (1972), 69 (10), 2904-9CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424.
        Methods for covalently joining duplex DNA mols. to one another have been developed and used to construct circular dimers of SV40 DNA and to insert a DNA segment contg. Î»-phage genes and the galactose operon of E. coli into SV40 DNA. The method involves: (a) converting circular SV40 DNA to a linear form, (b) adding single-stranded homodeoxypolymeric extensions of defined compn. and length to the 3' ends of 1 of the DNA strands with the enzyme terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase, (c) adding complementary homodeoxypolymeric extensions to the other DNA strand, (d) annealing the 2 DNA mols. to form a circular duplex structure, and (e) filling the gaps and sealing nicks in this structure with E. coli DNA polymerase and DNA ligase to form a covalently closed-circular DNA mol.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE3sXhslCh&md5=4afd92e56449c5d8cced628f9e174429
      15. 15
        Nadler, L. M.; Stashenko, P.; Hardy, R.; Kaplan, W. D.; Button, L. N.; Kufe, D. W.; Antman, K. H.; Schlossman, S. F. Serotherapy of a Patient with a Monoclonal Antibody Directed against a Human Lymphoma-Associated Antigen. Cancer Res. 1980, 40 (9), 3147â 3154
        [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        15
        Serotherapy of a patient with a monoclonal antibody directed against a human lymphoma-associated antigen
        Nadler L M; Stashenko P; Hardy R; Kaplan W D; Button L N; Kufe D W; Antman K H; Schlossman S F
        Cancer research (1980), 40 (9), 3147-54 ISSN:0008-5472.
        A preliminary serotherapeutic trial was undertaken with a monoclonal antibody designated antibody 89 (Ab 89) directed against a lymphoma-associated antigen. In vitro studies demonstrated that Ab 89 could mediate complement-dependent lysis and macrophage adherence but not antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity. To evaluate toxicity and therapeutic efficacy, two courses of Ab 89 were administered to a patient with an Ab 89-reactive tumor. Transient decreases in the number of circulating tumor cells and the appearance of circulating dead cells were noted with the infusion of Ab 89. Following administration of 150 mg or more of Ab 89, small amounts of antibody could be demonstrated on circulating tumor cells at a time when no free antibody was found in the serum. The inability to deliver a significant amount of Ab 89 to tumor cells in vivo is thought to be secondary to a circulating tumor antigen. Following each infusion, the amount of this blocking antigen decreased but could not be entirely cleared from the serum. This study provides preliminary evidence for the lack of clinical toxicity of a monoclonal antibody and identifies circulating blocking antigens as a significant obstacle to serotherapy.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADyaL3M%252Fkt1SlsA%253D%253D&md5=3490ac2a7f42fb531ecfc19bcb5fa649

      18. 18
        Bross, P. F.; Beitz, J.; Chen, G.; Chen, X. H.; Duffy, E.; Kieffer, L.; Roy, S.; Sridhara, R.; Rahman, A.; Williams, G.; Pazdur, R. Approval Summary: Gemtuzumab Ozogamicin in Relapsed Acute Myeloid Leukemia. Clin. Cancer Res. 2001, 7 (6), 1490â 1496
        [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        18
        Approval summary: Gemtuzumab ozogamicin in relapsed acute myeloid leukemia
        Bross, Peter F.; Beitz, Julie; Chen, Gang; Chen, Xiao Hong; Duffy, Eric; Kieffer, Lydia; Roy, Sandip; Sridhara, Rajeshwari; Rahman, Atiqur; Williams, Grant; Pazdur, Richard
        Clinical Cancer Research (2001), 7 (6), 1490-1496CODEN: CCREF4; ISSN:1078-0432. (American Association for Cancer Research)
        A review with refs. Gemtuzumab ozogamicin (Mylotarg; Wyeth Labs., Philadelphia, PA) consists of a semisynthetic deriv. of calicheamicin, a cytotoxic antibiotic linked to a recombinant monoclonal antibody directed against the CD33 antigen present on leukemic myeloblasts in most patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML). In this study, we review the preclin. and clin. profiles of this immuno-conjugate and the regulatory review that led to marketing approval by the United States Food and Drug Administration. From the literature and manufacturer's data, we review the activity, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of gemtuzumab ozogamicin in preclin. and Phase I studies and its activity, efficacy, and side effects in three Phase 2 trials of 142 patients with relapsed AML. In Phase I studies, the major toxicity was myelosuppression, esp. neutropenia and thrombocytopenia, resulting from the expression of CD33 on myeloid progenitor cells. The Phase 2 dose was 9 mg/m2 infused i.v. over 4 h, repeated on day 14. A minority of patients experienced acute infusion-related symptoms, usually transient and occasionally requiring hospitalization. The complete response (CR) rate with full recovery of hematopoiesis was 16%. A subset of patients [CRs with incomplete platelet recovery (CRps)] was identified with blast clearance and neutrophil recovery but incomplete platelet recovery. The duration of responses of CRps appeared to be similar to those of the CRs, although the nos. were small. The question of the equivalence of these response groups was a central issue in the review of this new drug application (NDA). After considerable discussion, the Oncol. Drugs Advisory Committee recommended allowing inclusion of CRps resulting in an overall response rate in the Phase 2 studies of 30%. In the subgroup of patients over 60 yr of age, the overall response rate was 26%. Response duration was difficult to establish because of the high prevalence of postremission therapies. Tolerability and ease of administration may be improved compared with conventional chemotherapy, except for hepatotoxicity, with 31% of patients exhibiting abnormal liver enzymes. One patient died of liver failure in the Phase 2 trials. Marketing approval of gemtuzumab ozogamicin was granted on May 17, 2000 by the United States Food and Drug Administration under the Accelerated Approval regulations. Gemtuzumab ozogamicin is indicated for the treatment of patients with CD33 pos. AML in first relapse who are 60 yr of age or older and who are not considered candidates for cytotoxic chemotherapy. The approved dose was 9 mg/m2 i.v. over 4 h and repeated in 14 days. Completion of the ongoing studies of gemtuzumab ozogamicin in relapsed AML and initiation of randomized clin. trials comparing the effects of gemtuzumab ozogamicin in combination with conventional induction chemotherapy to conventional chemotherapy alone on survival are mandated to confirm clin. benefit under the accelerated approval Subpart H regulations. Postmarketing reports of fatal anaphylaxis, adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and hepatotoxicity, esp. venoocclusive disease (VOD) in patients treated with gemtuzumab ozogamicin, with and without assocd. hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT), have required labeling revisions and the initiation of a registration surveillance program. Tumor lysis and ARDS have been reported in patients with leukocytes above 30,000/mL treated with gemtuzumab ozogamicin; therefore, the redn. of leukocyte counts to below 30,000/mL is recommended prior to treatment. Patients should be carefully monitored for acute hypersensitivity, hypoxia, and delayed hepatotoxicity following treatment with gemtuzumab ozogamicin.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXltV2iu78%253D&md5=8a85e32e3113034e98f05dfbd119110b

What are the implications for public health practice. The recommendation for the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine should be implemented in conjunction with ACIP's interim recommendation for allocating initial supplies of COVID-19 vaccines.

        22
        Creation of a bacterial cell controlled by a chemically synthesized genome
        Gibson, Daniel G.; Glass, John I.; Lartigue, Carole; Noskov, Vladimir N.; Chuang, Ray-Yuan; Algire, Mikkel A.; Benders, Gwynedd A.; Montague, Michael G.; Ma, Li; Moodie, Monzia M.; Merryman, Chuck; Vashee, Sanjay; Krishnakumar, Radha; Assad-Garcia, Nacyra; Andrews-Pfannkoch, Cynthia; Denisova, Evgeniya A.; Young, Lei; Qi, Zhi-Qing; Segall-Shapiro, Thomas H.; Calvey, Christopher H.; Parmar, Prashanth P.; Hutchison, Clyde A., III; Smith, Hamilton O.; Venter, J. Craig
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 329 (5987), 52-56CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        We report the design, synthesis, and assembly of the 1.08-mega-base pair Mycoplasma mycoides JCVI-syn1.0 genome starting from digitized genome sequence information and its transplantation into a M. capricolum recipient cell to create new M. mycoides cells that are controlled only by the synthetic chromosome. The only DNA in the cells is the designed synthetic DNA sequence, including "watermark" sequences and other designed gene deletions and polymorphisms, and mutations acquired during the building process. The new cells have expected phenotypic properties and are capable of continuous self-replication. The complete, annotated synthetic genome sequence is deposited in GenBank/EMBL/DDBJ with accession no. CP002027.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXotVeqsLg%253D&md5=f978c98f3e5c3c9b14bd4c7d8a1eecc7
      23. 23
        Malyshev, D. A.; Dhami, K.; Lavergne, T.; Chen, T.; Dai, N.; Foster, J. M.; CorrÃªa, I. R.; Romesberg, F. E. A Semi-Synthetic Organism with an Expanded Genetic Alphabet. Nature 2014, 509 (7500), 385â 388, Â DOI: 10.1038/nature13314
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        23
        A semi-synthetic organism with an expanded genetic alphabet
        Malyshev, Denis A.; Dhami, Kirandeep; Lavergne, Thomas; Chen, Tingjian; Dai, Nan; Foster, Jeremy M.; Correa, Ivan R.; Romesberg, Floyd E.
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2014), 509 (7500), 385-388CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Organisms are defined by the information encoded in their genomes, and since the origin of life this information has been encoded using a two-base-pair genetic alphabet (A-T and G-C). In vitro, the alphabet has been expanded to include several unnatural base pairs (UBPs). We have developed a class of UBPs formed between nucleotides bearing hydrophobic nucleobases, exemplified by the pair formed between d5SICS and dNaM (d5SICS-dNaM), which is efficiently PCR-amplified and transcribed in vitro, and whose unique mechanism of replication has been characterized. However, expansion of an organism's genetic alphabet presents new and unprecedented challenges: the unnatural nucleoside triphosphates must be available inside the cell; endogenous polymerases must be able to use the unnatural triphosphates to faithfully replicate DNA contg. the UBP within the complex cellular milieu; and finally, the UBP must be stable in the presence of pathways that maintain the integrity of DNA. Here we show that an exogenously expressed algal nucleotide triphosphate transporter efficiently imports the triphosphates of both d5SICS and dNaM (d5SICSTP and dNaMTP) into Escherichia coli, and that the endogenous replication machinery uses them to accurately replicate a plasmid contg. d5SICS-dNaM. Neither the presence of the unnatural triphosphates nor the replication of the UBP introduces a notable growth burden. Lastly, we find that the UBP is not efficiently excised by DNA repair pathways. Thus, the resulting bacterium is the first organism to propagate stably an expanded genetic alphabet.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXotVyqtb8%253D&md5=97b4b184cda52cc809b1705e5e88ad8e

        25
        A completely de novo ATPase from combinatorial protein design
        Wang, Michael S.; Hecht, Michael H.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2020), 142 (36), 15230-15234CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Our understanding of biol. chem. is shaped by the observation that all life comes from other life-as Pasteur put it, omne vivum ex vivo. A key step in expanding our biochem. vocabulary is to recapitulate biogenic catalysis using non-natural sequences that did not arise from common ancestry. Here we describe an enzyme designed completely de novo that hydrolyzes ATP. This protein was designed to lack Î²-sheet structure and is competitively inhibited by magnesium, two traits that are unlike natural ATPases.

        Brenner, D.; Blaser, H.; Mak, T. W. Regulation of Tumour Necrosis Factor Signalling: Live or Let Die. Nat. Rev. Immunol. 2015, 15 (6), 362â 374, Â DOI: 10.1038/nri3834
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        28
        Regulation of tumour necrosis factor signalling: live or let die
        Brenner, Dirk; Blaser, Heiko; Mak, Tak W.
        Nature Reviews Immunology (2015), 15 (6), 362-374CODEN: NRIABX; ISSN:1474-1733. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Tumor necrosis factor (TNF) is a pro-inflammatory cytokine that has important roles in mammalian immunity and cellular homeostasis. Deregulation of TNF receptor (TNFR) signalling is assocd. with many inflammatory disorders, including various types of arthritis and inflammatory bowel disease, and targeting TNF has been an effective therapeutic strategy in these diseases. This Review focuses on the recent advances that have been made in understanding TNFR signalling and the consequences of its deregulation for cellular survival, apoptosis and regulated necrosis. We discuss how TNF-induced survival signals are distinguished from those that lead to cell death. Finally, we provide a brief overview of the role of TNF in inflammatory and autoimmune diseases, and we discuss up-to-date and future treatment strategies for these disorders.

      29. 29
        Dinarello, C. A.; Simon, A.; van der Meer, J. W. M. Treating Inflammation by Blocking Interleukin-1 in a Broad Spectrum of Diseases. Nat. Rev. Drug Discovery 2012, 11 (8), 633â 652, Â DOI: 10.1038/nrd3800
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        29
        Treating inflammation by blocking interleukin-1 in a broad spectrum of diseases
        Dinarello, Charles A.; Simon, Anna; van der Meer, Jos W. M.
        Nature Reviews Drug Discovery (2012), 11 (8), 633-652CODEN: NRDDAG; ISSN:1474-1776. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. Interleukin-1 (IL-1) is a highly active pro-inflammatory cytokine that lowers pain thresholds and damages tissues. Monotherapy blocking IL-1 activity in autoinflammatory syndromes results in a rapid and sustained redn. in disease severity, including reversal of inflammation-mediated loss of sight, hearing and organ function. This approach can therefore be effective in treating common conditions such as post-infarction heart failure, and trials targeting a broad spectrum of new indications are underway. So far, three IL-1-targeted agents have been approved: the IL-1 receptor antagonist anakinra, the sol. decoy receptor rilonacept and the neutralizing monoclonal anti-IL-1Î² antibody canakinumab. In addn., a monoclonal antibody directed against the IL-1 receptor and a neutralizing anti-IL-1Î± antibody are in clin. trials.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XhtFWmtrfJ&md5=9297c8530f9d2c75da0880a7df7c1fe2

        Newman, D. J.; Cragg, G. M. Natural Products as Sources of New Drugs over the Nearly Four Decades from 01/1981 to 09/2019. J. Nat. Prod. 2020, 83 (3), 770â 803, Â DOI: 10.1021/acs.jnatprod.9b01285
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        30
        Natural Products as Sources of New Drugs over the Nearly Four Decades from 01/1981 to 09/2019
        Newman, David J.; Cragg, Gordon M.
        Journal of Natural Products (2020), 83 (3), 770-803CODEN: JNPRDF; ISSN:0163-3864. (American Chemical Society-American Society of Pharmacognosy)
        This review is an updated and expanded version of the five prior reviews that were published in this journal in 1997, 2003, 2007, 2012, and 2016. For all approved therapeutic agents, the time frame has been extended to cover the almost 39 years from the first of Jan. 1981 to the 30th of Sept. 2019 for all diseases worldwide and from â¼1946 (earliest so far identified) to the 30th of Sept. 2019 for all approved antitumor drugs worldwide. As in earlier reviews, only the first approval of any drug is counted, irresp. of how many "biosimilars" or added approvals were subsequently identified. As in the 2012 and 2016 reviews, we have continued to utilize our secondary subdivision of a "natural product mimic", or "NM", to join the original primary divisions, and the designation "natural product botanical", or "NB", to cover those botanical "defined mixts." now recognized as drug entities by the FDA (and similar organizations). From the data presented in this review, the utilization of natural products and/or synthetic variations using their novel structures, in order to discover and develop the final drug entity, is still alive and well. For example, in the area of cancer, over the time frame from 1946 to 1980, of the 75 small mols., 40, or 53.3%, are N or ND. In the 1981 to date time frame the equiv. figures for the N* compds. of the 185 small mols. are 62, or 33.5%, though to these can be added the 58 S* and S*/NMs, bringing the figure to 64.9%. In other areas, the influence of natural product structures is quite marked with, as expected from prior information, the anti-infective area being dependent on natural products and their structures, though as can be seen in the review there are still disease areas (shown in Table 2) for which there are no drugs derived from natural products. Although combinatorial chem. techniques have succeeded as methods of optimizing structures and have been used very successfully in the optimization of many recently approved agents, we are still able to identify only two de novo combinatorial compds. (one of which is a little speculative) approved as drugs in this 39-yr time frame, though there is also one drug that was developed using the "fragment-binding methodol." and approved in 2012. We have also added a discussion of candidate drug entities currently in clin. trials as "warheads" and some very interesting preliminary reports on sources of novel antibiotics from Nature due to the abs. requirement for new agents to combat plasmid-borne resistance genes now in the general populace. We continue to draw the attention of readers to the recognition that a significant no. of natural product drugs/leads are actually produced by microbes and/or microbial interactions with the "host from whence it was isolated"; thus we consider that this area of natural product research should be expanded significantly.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXks1Cmsrw%253D&md5=2c10c2aef98042d8bd772b6280b51d2b
      31. 31
        Yu, H.; MacIsaac, D.; Wong, J. J.; Sellers, Z. M.; Wren, A. A.; Bensen, R.; Kin, C.; Park, K. T. Market Share and Costs of Biologic Therapies for Inflammatory Bowel Disease in the USA. Aliment. Pharmacol. Ther. 2018, 47 (3), 364â 370, Â DOI: 10.1111/apt.14430
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        31
        Market share and costs of biologic therapies for inflammatory bowel disease in the USA
        Yu, H.; MacIsaac, D.; Wong, J. J.; Sellers, Z. M.; Wren, A. A.; Bensen, R.; Kin, C.; Park, K. T.
        Alimentary Pharmacology and Therapeutics (2018), 47 (3), 364-370CODEN: APTHEN; ISSN:0269-2813. (Wiley-Blackwell)
        Summary : Background : Real-world data quantifying the costs of increasing use of biologics in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) are unknown. Aim : To det. the outpatient IBD drug utilization trends, relative market share, and costs in the USA during a 9-yr period. Methods : The Truven MarketScan Database was analyzed for patients with Crohn's disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC) during 2007-2015. National drug codes were used to identify prescription drugs; Healthcare Common Procedure Coding System J-codes were used to capture biol. out-patient infusions. Proportion of drug usage, relative market share and per-member per-yr (PMPY) costs were analyzed for biologics, immunomodulators, 5-ASAs and corticosteroids. Results : In 415 405 patients (188 842 CD; 195 183 UC; 31 380 indeterminate colitis; 54.67% female), utilization trends show a consistent rise in the market share of biologics during the 9-yr study period. The proportion of patients using biologics increased from 21.8% to 43.8% for CD and 5.1%-16.2% for UC. This contrasts a small decrease in immunomodulator and 5-ASA use for CD and relative constancy of other classes including corticosteroids-only use as primary IBD medication from 2007 to 2015. The av. biol.-taking patient accounted for 25 275 PMPY in 2007 and 36 051 PMPY in 2015. The av. paediatric biol.-taking patient accounted for 23 616 PMPY in 2007 and 41 109 PMPY in 2015. In all patients, the share of costs for biologics increased from 72.9% in 2007 to 85.7% in 2015 (81.7% in 2007 to 94.9% in 2015 in paediatrics). Conclusion : The vast majority of costs allocated to out-patient IBD medications in the USA is attributed to increasing use of biol. therapies despite the relative minority of biol.-taking patients.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXmt1elsg%253D%253D&md5=bc8bb2062cef56a3c2b6ec7343060353
      32. 32
        Hirsch, B. R.; Balu, S.; Schulman, K. A. The Impact Of Specialty Pharmaceuticals As Drivers Of Health Care Costs. Health Aff. 2014, 33 (10), 1714â 1720, Â DOI: 10.1377/hlthaff.2014.0558
        [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        32
        The impact of specialty pharmaceuticals as drivers of health care costs
        Hirsch Bradford R; Balu Suresh; Schulman Kevin A
        Health affairs (Project Hope) (2014), 33 (10), 1714-20 ISSN:.
        The pharmaceutical industry is shifting its focus from blockbuster small molecules to specialty pharmaceuticals. Specialty pharmaceuticals are novel drugs and biologic agents that require special handling and ongoing monitoring, are administered by injection or infusion, and are sold in the marketplace by a small number of distributors. They are frequently identified by having a cost to payers and patients of $600 or more per treatment. The total costs of the new agents are likely to have a substantial impact on overall health care costs and on patients during the next decade, unless steps are taken to align competing interests. We examine the economic and policy issues related to specialty pharmaceuticals, taking care to consider the impact on patients. We assess the role of cost-sharing provisions, legislation that is promoting realignment within the market, the role of biosimilars in price competition, and the potential for novel drug development paradigms to help bend the cost curve. The economic aspects of this analysis highlight the need for a far-reaching discussion of potential novel approaches to innovation pathways in our quest for both affordability and new technology.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC2M7otVKjug%253D%253D&md5=1cecaafff39d7069104b734d5f06f6cc

        Krall, N.; da Cruz, F. P.; Boutureira, O.; Bernardes, G. J. L. Site-Selective Protein-Modification Chemistry for Basic Biology and Drug Development. Nat. Chem. 2016, 8 (2), 103â 113, Â DOI: 10.1038/nchem.2393

        36
        Site-selective protein-modification chemistry for basic biology and drug development
        Krall, Nikolaus; da Cruz, Filipa P.; Boutureira, Omar; Bernardes, Goncalo J. L.
        Nature Chemistry (2016), 8 (2), 103-113CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
        A review. Nature has produced intricate machinery to covalently diversify the structure of proteins after their synthesis in the ribosome. In an attempt to mimic nature, chemists have developed a large set of reactions that enable post-expression modification of proteins at pre-detd. sites. These reactions are now used to selectively install particular modifications on proteins for many biol. and therapeutic applications. For example, they provide an opportunity to install post-translational modifications on proteins to det. their exact biol. roles. Labeling of proteins in live cells with fluorescent dyes allows protein uptake and intracellular trafficking to be tracked and also enables physiol. parameters to be measured optically. Through the conjugation of potent cytotoxicants to antibodies, novel anti-cancer drugs with improved efficacy and reduced side effects may be obtained. In this Perspective, we highlight the most exciting current and future applications of chem. site-selective protein modification and consider which hurdles still need to be overcome for more widespread use.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhvFemsbrI&md5=9a8f675a512f1286c5d88c6692d8773c

        Adamo, R.; Nilo, A.; Castagner, B.; Boutureira, O.; Berti, F.; Bernardes, G. J. L. Synthetically Defined Glycoprotein Vaccines: Current Status and Future Directions. Chem. Sci. 2013, 4 (8), 2995â 3008, Â DOI: 10.1039/c3sc50862e
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar

        Synthetically defined glycoprotein vaccines: current status and future directions
        Adamo, Roberto; Nilo, Alberto; Castagner, Bastien; Boutureira, Omar; Berti, Francesco; Bernardes, Goncalo J. L.
        Chemical Science (2013), 4 (8), 2995-3008CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Primary examples in vaccine design have shown good levels of carbohydrate-specific antibody generation when raised using extd. or fully synthetic capsular polysaccharide glycans covalently coupled to a protein carrier. Herein, the authors cover recent clin. developments of carbohydrate-based vaccines and describe how novel cutting-edge methodol. for the total synthesis of oligosaccharides and for the precise placement of carbohydrates at pre-detd. sites within a protein may be used to further improve the safety and efficacy of glycovaccines.

        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtVehs7jN&md5=eb09336f0a6302efb364de7539fd94a4
      38. 38
        Danishefsky, S. J.; Allen, J. R. From the Laboratory to the Clinic: A Retrospective on Fully Synthetic Carbohydrate-Based Anticancer Vaccines. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2000, 39 (5), 836â 863, Â DOI: 10.1002/(SICI)1521-3773(20000303)39:5<836::AID-ANIE836>3.0.CO;2-I
        [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        38
        From the laboratory to the clinic: a retrospective on fully synthetic carbohydrate-based anticancer vaccines
        Danishefsky, Samuel J.; Allen, Jennifer R.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2000), 39 (5), 836-863CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        A review with many refs. on authors' explorations into oligosaccharide and glycoconjugate construction for the creation and evaluation of vaccines based on carbohydrate-centered tumor antigens. The starting point was the known tendency of transformed cells to express selective carbohydrate motifs in the form of glycoproteins or glycolipids. Anticancer vaccines derived from carbohydrate-based antigens could be effective targets for immune recognition and attack. Obtaining significant quantities of such structures from natural sources is extremely difficult. With the total synthesis of tumor-assocd. carbohydrate antigens accomplished, the evaluation at the clin. level was initiated whether the human immune system can respond to such fully synthetic antigens in a focused and useful way. Toward this goal the resources of chem. and immunol. in an attack on the problem were merged. The synthesis and immunoconjugation of various tumor-assocd. carbohydrate antigens and the results of such constructs in mice vaccinations are described. For fashioning an effective vaccine, conjugation to a suitable immunogenic carrier was necessary and conjugates of keyhole limpet cyanin have consistently demonstrated the relevant immunogenicity. Preclin. and clin. studies with synthetic conjugate carbohydrate vaccines show induction of IgM- and IgG-antibody responses. Another approach to anticancer vaccines involves the use of clustered glycopeptides as targets for immune attack. Initial attention has been directed to mucin-related O-linked glycopeptides. Synthetic trimeric clusters of glycoepitopes derived from the Tn-, TF- and Lewisy-antigens, appropriately bioconjugated, have been demonstrated to be immunogenic. The hope is that patients immunized in an adjuvant manner with synthetic carbohydrate vaccines would produce antibodies reactive with cancer cells and that the prodn. of such antibodies would mitigate against tumor spread, thereby enabling a more favorable survival and "quality of life" prognosis.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXhvFSns7s%253D&md5=0a800658fba553abe968b57db53ce28e
      39. 39
        Pelegri-OâDay, E. M.; Lin, E.-W.; Maynard, H. D. Therapeutic Protein-Polymer Conjugates: Advancing Beyond PEGylation. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2014, 136 (41), 14323â 14332, Â DOI: 10.1021/ja504390x
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        39
        Therapeutic Protein-Polymer Conjugates: Advancing Beyond PEGylation
        Pelegri-O'Day, Emma M.; Lin, En-Wei; Maynard, Heather D.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136 (41), 14323-14332CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Protein-polymer conjugates are widely used as therapeutics. All Food and Drug Administration (FDA)-approved protein conjugates are covalently linked to poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG). These PEGylated drugs have longer half-lives in the bloodstream, leading to less frequent dosing, which is a significant advantage for patients. However, there are some potential drawbacks to PEG that are driving the development of alternatives. Polymers that display enhanced pharmacokinetic properties along with addnl. advantages such as improved stability or degradability will be important to advance the field of protein therapeutics. This perspective presents a summary of protein-PEG conjugates for therapeutic use and alternative technologies in various stages of development as well as suggestions for future directions. Established methods of producing protein-PEG conjugates and new approaches utilizing controlled radical polymn. are also covered.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

        Lambert, J. M.; Berkenblit, A. Antibody-Drug Conjugates for Cancer Treatment. Annu. Rev. Med. 2018, 69 (1), 191â 207, Â DOI: 10.1146/annurev-med-061516-121357
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        40
        Antibody-Drug Conjugates for Cancer Treatment
        Lambert, John M.; Berkenblit, Anna
        Annual Review of Medicine (2018), 69 (), 191-207CODEN: ARMCAH; ISSN:0066-4219. (Annual Reviews)
        A review. The concept of exploiting the specific binding properties of monoclonal antibodies as a mechanism for selective delivery of cytotoxic agents to tumor cells is an attractive soln. to the challenge of increasing the therapeutic index of cell-killing agents for treating cancer. All three parts of an antibody-drug conjugate (ADC)-the antibody, the cytotoxic payload, and the linker chem. that joins them together-as well as the biol. properties of the cell-surface target antigen are important in designing an effective anticancer agent. The approval of brentuximab vedotin in 2011 for treating relapsed Hodgkin's lymphoma and systemic anaplastic large cell lymphoma, and the approval of ado-trastuzumab emtansine in 2013 for treating HER2-pos. metastatic breast cancer, have sparked vigorous research in the field, with >65 ADCs currently in clin. evaluation. This review highlights the ADCs that are approved for marketing, in pivotal clin. trials, or in at least phase II clin. development for treating both hematol. malignancies and solid tumors.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®

        Cernak, T.; Dykstra, K. D.; Tyagarajan, S.; Vachal, P.; Krska, S. W. The Medicinal Chemistâs Toolbox for Late Stage Functionalization of Drug-like Molecules. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2016, 45 (3), 546â 576, Â DOI: 10.1039/C5CS00628G
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        42
        The medicinal chemist's toolbox for late stage functionalization of drug-like molecules
        Cernak, Tim; Dykstra, Kevin D.; Tyagarajan, Sriram; Vachal, Petr; Krska, Shane W.
        Chemical Society Reviews (2016), 45 (3), 546-576CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        The advent of modern C-H functionalization chemistries has enabled medicinal chemists to consider a synthetic strategy, late stage functionalization (LSF), which utilizes the C-H bonds of drug leads as points of diversification for generating new analogs. LSF approaches offer the promise of rapid exploration of structure activity relationships (SAR), the generation of oxidized metabolites, the blocking of metabolic hot spots and the prepn. of biol. probes. This review details a toolbox of intermol. C-H functionalization chemistries with proven applicability to drug-like mols., classified by regioselectivity patterns, and gives guidance on how to systematically develop LSF strategies using these patterns and other considerations. In addn., a no. of examples illustrate how LSF approaches have been used to impact actual drug discovery and chem. biol. efforts.

        The Evolution of High-Throughput Experimentation in Pharmaceutical Development and Perspectives on the Future
        Mennen, Steven M.; Alhambra, Carolina; Allen, C. Liana; Barberis, Mario; Berritt, Simon; Brandt, Thomas A.; Campbell, Andrew D.; Castanon, Jesus; Cherney, Alan H.; Christensen, Melodie; Damon, David B.; Eugenio de Diego, J.; Garcia-Cerrada, Susana; Garcia-Losada, Pablo; Haro, Ruben; Janey, Jacob; Leitch, David C.; Li, Ling; Liu, Fangfang; Lobben, Paul C.; MacMillan, David W. C.; Magano, Javier; McInturff, Emma; Monfette, Sebastien; Post, Ronald J.; Schultz, Danielle; Sitter, Barbara J.; Stevens, Jason M.; Strambeanu, Iulia I.; Twilton, Jack; Wang, Ke; Zajac, Matthew A.
        Organic Process Research & Development (2019), 23 (6), 1213-1242CODEN: OPRDFK; ISSN:1083-6160. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. High-throughput experimentation (HTE) has revolutionized the pharmaceutical industry, most notably allowing for rapid screening of compd. libraries against therapeutic targets. The past decade has also witnessed the extension of HTE principles toward the realm of small-mol. process chem. Today, most major pharmaceutical companies have created dedicated HTE groups within their process development teams, invested in automation technol. to accelerate screening, or both. The industry's commitment to accelerating process development has led to rapid innovations in the HTE space. This review will deliver an overview of the latest best practices currently taking place within our teams in process chem. by sharing frequently studied transformations, our perspective for the next several years in the field, and manual and automated tools to enable experimentation. A series of case studies are presented to exemplify state-of-the-art workflows developed within our labs.

        Sato, A. K.; Viswanathan, M.; Kent, R. B.; Wood, C. R. Therapeutic Peptides: Technological Advances Driving Peptides into Development. Curr. Opin. Biotechnol. 2006, 17 (6), 638â 642, Â DOI: 10.1016/j.copbio.2006.10.002
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        44
        Therapeutic peptides: Technological advances driving peptides into development
        Sato, Aaron K.; Viswanathan, Malini; Kent, Rachel B.; Wood, Clive R.
        Current Opinion in Biotechnology (2006), 17 (6), 638-642CODEN: CUOBE3; ISSN:0958-1669. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A review. As potential therapeutics, peptides offer several advantages over small mols. (increased specificity) and antibodies (small size). Nevertheless, a no. of key issues have hampered their use as drug candidates. A series of new technologies have recently been developed that allow peptides to be viable drug candidates in areas usually restricted to protein therapeutics, such as monoclonal antibodies. These include the development of various types of peptide-conjugates that have lower rates of clearance and hence the potential to increase the exposure of peptide drug candidates in chronic diseases. Structural addns. were also made to peptides, including the use of unnatural amino acids, main-chain modifications, and other novel substitutions, which have helped to improve peptide stability and further their therapeutic potential.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xht1eqs7zL&md5=c29eae8a5bbf2e0bb5fb3c67211be0d5

        Di, L. Strategic Approaches to Optimizing Peptide ADME Properties. AAPS J. 2015, 17 (1), 134â 143, Â DOI: 10.1208/s12248-014-9687-3
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        45
        Strategic Approaches to Optimizing Peptide ADME Properties
        Di, Li
        AAPS Journal (2015), 17 (1), 134-143CODEN: AJAOB6; ISSN:1550-7416. (Springer)
        Development of peptide drugs is challenging but also quite rewarding. Five blockbuster peptide drugs are currently on the market, and six new peptides received first marketing approval as new mol. entities in 2012. Although peptides only represent 2% of the drug market, the market is growing twice as quickly and might soon occupy a larger niche. Natural peptides typically have poor absorption, distribution, metab., and excretion (ADME) properties with rapid clearance, short half-life, low permeability, and sometimes low soly. Strategies have been developed to improve peptide drugability through enhancing permeability, reducing proteolysis and renal clearance, and prolonging half-life. In vivo, in vitro, and in silico tools are available to evaluate ADME properties of peptides, and structural modification strategies are in place to improve peptide developability.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXhvFSnurvJ&md5=530597d3719d65509105096f433fee0a
      46. 46
        Werle, M.; Bernkop-SchnÃ¼rch, A. Strategies to Improve Plasma Half Life Time of Peptide and Protein Drugs. Amino Acids 2006, 30 (4), 351â 367, Â DOI: 10.1007/s00726-005-0289-3
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        46
        Strategies to improve plasma half life time of peptide and protein drugs
        Werle, M.; Bernkop-Schnuerch, A.
        Amino Acids (2006), 30 (4), 351-367CODEN: AACIE6; ISSN:0939-4451. (Springer Wien)
        A review. Due to the obvious advantages of long-acting peptide and protein drugs, strategies to prolong blood plasma half life time of such compds. are highly on demand. Short plasma half life times are commonly due to fast renal clearance as well as to enzymic degrdn. occurring during systemic circulation. Modifications of the peptide/protein can lead to prolonged plasma half life times. By shortening the overall amino acid amt. of somatostatin and replacing L-analog amino acids with D-amino acids, plasma half life time of the derivate octreotide was 1.5 h in comparison to only few minutes of somatostatin. A PEG2,40K conjugate of INF-Î±-2b exhibited a 330-fold prolonged plasma half life time compared to the native protein. It was the aim of this review to provide an overview of possible strategies to prolong plasma half life time such as modification of N- and C-terminus or PEGylation as well as methods to evaluate the effectiveness of drug modifications. Furthermore, fundamental data about most important proteolytic enzymes of human blood, liver, and kidney as well as their cleavage specificity and inhibitors for them are provided to predict enzymic cleavage of peptide and protein drugs during systemic circulation.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28Xls1egsrw%253D&md5=2e286c53028f38cfe33deef26bb160d0
      47. 47
        Rand, A. C.; Leung, S. S. F.; Eng, H.; Rotter, C. J.; Sharma, R.; Kalgutkar, A. S.; Zhang, Y.; Varma, M. V.; Farley, K. A.; Khunte, B.; Limberakis, C.; Price, D. A.; Liras, S.; Mathiowetz, A. M.; Jacobson, M. P.; Lokey, R. S. Optimizing PK Properties of Cyclic Peptides: The Effect of Side Chain Substitutions on Permeability and Clearance.         A series of cyclic peptides were designed and prepd. to investigate the physicochem. properties that affect oral bioavailability of this chemotype in rats. In particular, the ionization state of the peptide was examd. by the incorporation of naturally occurring amino acid residues that are charged in differing regions of the gut. In addn., data was generated in a variety of in vitro assays and the usefulness of this data in predicting the subsequent oral bioavailability obsd. in the rat is discussed.

        A review. Antibodies constitute the most rapidly growing class of human therapeutics and the second largest class of drugs after vaccines.         Optimization of protein therapeutics by directed evolution
        Vasserot, Alain P.; Dickinson, Craig D.; Tang, Ying; Huse, William D.; Manchester, Keith S.; Watkins, Jeffry D.
        Drug Discovery Today (2003), 8 (3), 118-126CODEN: DDTOFS; ISSN:1359-6446. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
        A review. Directed evolution is a broadly applicable technol. platform that is ideally suited to address the need for protein optimization and to fully exploit the therapeutic potential of biologics. The approach takes advantage of the remarkable structural and functional plasticity of proteins and permits the rapid remodeling of biologics into new entities with improved functions. The ability to ameliorate virtually any characteristic of a protein can translate into significant clin. benefits, including decreased immunogenicity, higher potency, greater efficacy and improved safety profile, and can considerably increase the probability of successfully developing and commercializing biotherapeutics.

        Gaberc-Porekar, V.; Zore, I.; Podobnik, B.; Menart, V. Obstacles and Pitfalls in the PEGylation of Therapeutic Proteins. Curr. Opin. Drug Discovery Devel. 2008, 11 (2), 242â 250
        [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        50
        Obstacles and pitfalls in the PEGylation of therapeutic proteins
        Gaberc-Porekar, Vladka; Zore, Irena; Podobnik, Barbara; Menart, Viktor
        Current Opinion in Drug Discovery & Development (2008), 11 (2), 242-250CODEN: CODDFF; ISSN:1367-6733. (Thomson Scientific)
        A review. In recent years, PEGylation has become widely used as a post-prodn. modification methodol. for improving the biomedical efficacy and physicochem. properties of therapeutic proteins. Several marketed drugs that have already been in use for more than a decade have proved the applicability and safety of this technol. and, with the successes already achieved, it is expected that PEGylation will be applied to other potential therapeutic proteins. The non-biodegradable nature of PEG, however, may become a limiting factor for the next generation of protein pharmaceuticals, for which use in high concns. and in the long term is the aim, esp. considering the trend for the use of branched and high mol. mass PEGs. This review addresses various obstacles and pitfalls in the prodn. of PEGylated biopharmaceuticals, in particular, the specificity of PEGylation reactions, sepn. and purifn. issues, the anal. of inherently polydisperse PEG reagents and PEGylated products, the consistency of products and processes, and the accurate detn. of pharmacokinetic properties.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1cXivFektr8%253D&md5=01d9ff6b0f69299ea8cf1ed2b2db74a7

        Dozier, J.; Distefano, M. Site-Specific PEGylation of Therapeutic Proteins. Int. J. Mol. Sci. 2015, 16 (10), 25831â 25864, Â DOI: 10.3390/ijms161025831
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        51
        Site-specific pegylation of therapeutic proteins
        Dozier, Jonathan K.; Distefano, Mark D.
        International Journal of Molecular Sciences (2015), 16 (10), 25831-25864CODEN: IJMCFK; ISSN:1422-0067. (MDPI AG)
        The use of proteins as therapeutics has a long history and is becoming ever more common in modern medicine. While the no. of protein-based drugs is growing every year, significant problems still remain with their use. Among these problems are rapid degrdn. and excretion from patients, thus requiring frequent dosing, which in turn increases the chances for an immunol. response as well as increasing the cost of therapy. One of the main strategies to alleviate these problems is to link a polyethylene glycol (PEG) group to the protein of interest. This process, called PEGylation, has grown dramatically in recent years resulting in several approved drugs. Installing a single PEG chain at a defined site in a protein is challenging. Recently, there is has been considerable research into various methods for the site-specific PEGylation of proteins. This review seeks to summarize that work and provide background and context for how site-specific PEGylation is performed. After introducing the topic of site-specific PEGylation, recent developments using chem. methods are described. That is followed by a more extensive discussion of bioorthogonal reactions and enzymic labeling.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtFaltrfF&md5=e07d153e16a67da1e929964ec7ba01bf
      52. 52
        Hoyt, E. A.; Cal, P. M. S. D.; Oliveira, B. L.; Bernardes, G. J. L. Contemporary Approaches to Site-Selective Protein Modification. Nat. Rev. Chem. 2019, 3 (3), 147â 171, Â DOI: 10.1038/s41570-019-0079-1
        [Crossref], [CAS],Â Google Scholar
        52
        Contemporary approaches to site-selective protein modification
        Hoyt, Emily A.; Cal, Pedro M. S. D.; Oliveira, Bruno L.; Bernardes, Goncalo J. L.
        Nature Reviews Chemistry (2019), 3 (3), 147-171CODEN: NRCAF7; ISSN:2397-3358. (Nature Research)
        Proteins constitute the majority of nature's worker biomols. Designed for specific functions, complex tertiary structures make proteins ideal candidates for analyzing natural systems and creating novel biol. tools. Owing to both their large size and the need for proper folding, de novo synthesis of proteins has been quite a challenge, leading scientists to focus on modifying protein templates already provided by nature. Recently developed methods for protein modification fall into two broad categories: those that can modify the natural protein template directly and those that require genetic manipulation of the amino acid sequence before modification. The goal of this Review is not only to provide a window through which to view the many opportunities created by novel protein modification techniques, but also to act as an initial guide to help scientists find direction and form ideas in an ever-growing field. In addn. to highlighting methods reported in the past 5 years, we aim to provide a broader sense of the goals and outcomes of protein modification and bioconjugation in general. While the main body of this paper comprises reactions involving the direct modification of expressed proteins, some further functionalization strategies as well as biol. applications are also acknowledged. The discussion concludes by speculating which trends and discoveries will most likely come next in the field.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXnsFCks7o%253D&md5=b08dabd1a572061e988c0ee1d64d71d2

        Residue-Specific Peptide Modification: A Chemist's Guide
        deGruyter, Justine N.; Malins, Lara R.; Baran, Phil S.
        Biochemistry (2017), 56 (30), 3863-3873CODEN: BICHAW; ISSN:0006-2960. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Advances in bioconjugation and native protein modification are appearing at a blistering pace, making it increasingly time consuming for practitioners to identify the best chem. method to modify a specific amino acid residue in a complex setting. The purpose of this perspective is to provide an informative, graphically rich manual highlighting significant advances in the field over the past decade. This guide will help triage candidate methods for peptide alteration, and will serve as a starting point for those seeking to solve longstanding challenges.

        54
        Decarboxylative alkylation for site-selective bioconjugation of native proteins via oxidation potentials
        Bloom, Steven; Liu, Chun; Kolmel, Dominik K.; Qiao, Jennifer X.; Zhang, Yong; Poss, Michael A.; Ewing, William R.; MacMillan, David W. C.
        Nature Chemistry (2018), 10 (2), 205-211CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Research)
        The advent of antibody-drug conjugates as pharmaceuticals has fueled a need for reliable methods of site-selective protein modification that furnish homogeneous adducts. Although bioorthogonal methods that use engineered amino acids often provide an elegant soln. to the question of selective functionalization, achieving homogeneity using native amino acids remains a challenge. Here, the authors explore visible-light-mediated single-electron transfer as a mechanism towards enabling site- and chemoselective bioconjugation. Specifically, the authors demonstrate the use of photoredox catalysis as a platform to selectivity wherein the discrepancy in oxidn. potentials between internal vs. C-terminal carboxylates can be exploited towards obtaining C-terminal functionalization exclusively. This oxidn. potential-gated technol. is amenable to endogenous peptides and has been successfully demonstrated on the protein insulin. As a fundamentally new approach to bioconjugation this methodol. provides a blueprint toward the development of photoredox catalysis as a generic platform to target other redox-active side chains for native conjugation.
        >> More from SciFinder Â®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhvFWgsrjJ&md5=a5f8b7f701329a625221c77280243746
